Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: new-heritage-website-showcases-east-lothian-heritage
story: The Salt of the Earth Heritage Connections site was launched last month as a hub for locals to view heritage groups and projects in East Lothian.Jill De Fresnes, project officer, said: “We are so pleased with the website.“It really reflects the colour and richness of the area’s heritage and history.“We see it as an important part of the lottery-funded Salt of the Earth project and the legacy we will be leaving when the project finishes later this year.”The site is an accessible way for the project to develop a heritage network across the Preston Seton Gosford ward, where groups and iniduals can connect and share heritage stories, images and videos.News stories and discoveries are also highlighted, with a group calender offering a quick and easy way to see what is going on in the area.Jill added: “As it develops further, we are hoping to have a forum for discussion and there is a map highlighting specic areas or sites of interest. This is particularly useful for any potential visitors, who can see what an incredible wealth of heritage there is here: the built heritage, archaeology, natural heritage, as well as stories, art and culture, and we will also be linking up with Visit East Lothian to help promote the area.”Ed Bethune, of Bethune Heritage, developed the site – Jill added that they were “very lucky to have him”.Ed said: “The website has been developed over the past six months but has just officially launched.“We’re aiming to ensure that there is a lasting legacy for the Salt of the Earth Heritage Connections project, so the website and social media channels created during the project will be used to help keep our local heritage groups connected, active and successful in the longer term.“It’s a really exciting way to empower local heritage and build on the great work that Salt of the Earth has done in Preston, Seton and Gosford.”To view the new website, visit saltoftheearth heritage

title: overnight-closure-section-a1-east-lothian-next-week
story: Carriageway repairs are planned for the westbound section of the road at Old Craighall Junction on Friday, February .The work will take place between pm and .am the following day.Traffic will be erted off the A at Old Craighall Junction via the westbound off-slip road, then back on again via the westbound on-slip road between those times.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotland’s network manager for the south east, said: “A carriageway closure is necessary to allow us to complete these repairs safely however, we don’t expect these works to cause any signicant delays to traffic as the ersion is very short.”The work is weather dependent and could be postponed due to adverse weather conditions.For more information, go to trafficscotland.org

title: easter-bunny-hand-eggs-tranent
story: Little Bundle of Joy Baby Boutique, on High Street, will welcome Mr Fluffy the Easter bunny on April , between am and pm.During the Easter visit, Mr Fluffy will hand out chocolate eggs to each child, with families given the opportunity to take a picture with the rabbit.Tickets can be purchased in store, costing £ per child.

title: mp-praises-fundraising-young-footballers
story: Pencaitland Youth Football Club teamed up with the village’s bowling club to help raise funds to buy a defibrillator.The potentially le-saving device gives a high-energy electric shock to the heart of someone in cardiac arrest. The high-energy shock – defibrillation – is an essential part of trying to save the le of someone in cardiac arrest.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, wrote to the football club to congratulate them on their efforts and submitted an Early Day Motion at Westminster.He said: “I am aware that Pencaitland Youth Football Club has recently raised funds for a defibrillator for the local community.“I am very pleased to extend my congratulations to you all on your successful participation in walking  miles around the community, and commend the dedication of completing this during a cold December.”The motion, which was submitted last month, calls on the House of Commons to recognise the youngsters for their efforts.It reads: “That this House commends Pencaitland Youth Football Club for working alongside Pencaitland Bowling Club to raise funds for a defibrillator congratulates the club on their success of raising over £, by covering  miles by walking round the village’s park before Christmas  with their parents and coaches for the le-saving device notes that the defibrillator will be sited at Pencaitland Bowling Club for use by members of the public in an emergency wishes Pencaitland Youth Football Club the best of luck with their futures.”

title: parent-council-questions-new-nursery-sustainability
story: The two-storey nursery building will be built west of Law Primary School and will replace the town’s current nursery on Law Road.However, Law Primary School’s parent council has raised concerns about the “lack of thinking around how families will travel to the nursery in a more sustainable and healthy way”.Construction is due to start next month, with the facility due to be completed by next year.The new building will feature a play area and garden to the north of the nursery, prompting criticism by parents of the building’s energy sustainability.Kate Allen, chairperson of Law Primary School Parent Council, said: “Our main frustrations have been the lack of thinking around how families will travel to the nursery in a more sustainable and healthy way, and how the nursery should be built to be as climate friendly as possible.”The parent council originally objected to the plans for the facility in May , citing two key points around creating better paths for travel and a reorientation of the building to utilise more natural light.New plans from East Lothian Councilwere released in December, with parents claiming that “very few changes to the original plans from May” had been made.The site of the new planned new early years centre at Law Primary School, North BerwickKate added: “We wrote to ELC in December asking for them to explain why this was and they never replied.“Then the plans were passed in January  without any further discussions.”Although a travel plan was not submitted in the nursery build’s original application, the council did meet with the parent council in May last year to discuss its concerns, and then submitted a comprehensive travel plan, which included many of the parents’ suggestions for future paths.The council has not, however, responded to parent council questions regarding the reorientation of the building.Kate said: “The latest report is completely unsatisfactory in terms of an explanation.“There may be a good reason but we are yet to hear one.“It was our belief that the buildings department would have to work with East Lothian Council’s Climate Change Strategy to ensure new building work should be as climate friendly as possible.“This is the question we believe needs asking of the council – are they using their Climate Change Strategy when they brief architects  If not, why not ”She added: “The delay to the build is so frustrating for staff and parents and we have only objected because we feel that these issues are so important – we want to get it right for future generations.”An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: “The project team has engaged with and responded comprehensively to the queries raised throughout this project both in discussions with Parent Council and Planning Department. This includes extensive information provided on the building’s energy and sustainability, which led to planning permission being granted."We have committed to providing a low carbon and sustainable nursery building in a - learning campus that supports the local community and provides a healthy and resilient natural environment for the future. This is in line with our Climate Change Strategy.“The development will offer learners, staff and the community all the benefits of moving from an older, much less energy-efficient building to a new, more sustainable, high-quality, purpose-built facility with multiple access routes to encourage sustainable travel.“The nursery building’s orientation within that campus of north  south is also very important. The main building access is orientated to the south from Old Haddington Road to allow ease of access for those with additional support needs, as well as addressing the close relationship to the main primary school building, of which the nursery is a part.“Energy efficiency has been considered carefully throughout the building’s design and specication and we aim to combine this with sustainable building practices and reduce emissions where possible throughout the construction.”The new nursery, which will have capacity for  children over two sessions, has an open-plan design, with a mezz- anine area and separate quiet room.The contract value of the nursery is £. million, with a further £, due to be spent on internal fittings.North of the site, a three-classroom extension for secondary-school pupils is being built on the south-west side of North Berwick High School.This £. million project, due to be completed next autumn, will house new home economics, modern languages and social studies classrooms for the high school.

title: pmqs-today-watch-live-stream-scotland
story: Earlier this week Keir Starmer was mobbed by protestors yelling Saville slurs.Johnson had previously ly claimed the opposition leader “used his time prosecuting journalists and failing to prosecute Jimmy Savile” while Director of Public Prosecutions.After the incident occurred, Johnson tweeted the “behaviour directed” at the Labour leader was “absolutely disgraceful”. However, he did not address the nature of the abuse.The behaviour directed at the Leader of the Opposition tonight is absolutely disgraceful. All forms of harassment of our elected representatives are completely unacceptable.I thank the police for responding swtly.Speaking to Sky News yesterday, Nicola Sturgeon said she believes Boris Johnson should “fully, unreservedly and unequivocally apologise” to Keir Starmer.“It is unbefitting behaviour of someone in Boris Johnson’s position. If he has a single shred of decency he will withdraw his comments that he made completely and he will fully, unreservedly and unequivocally apologise to Keir Starmer.”If he has a single shred of decency, he will withdraw his comments.@NicolaSturgeon says Boris Johnson must "fully, unreservedly and unequivocally apologise" to Sir Keir Starmer following his Jimmy Savile remarks.https:t.co JqhWkcFp📺 Sky , Virgin , Freeview  pic NaFgqRMqNShe continued: “We should all draw the line at bringing the smears and the lies and the conspiracy theories of the far-right and the other trolls that populate social media into the mainstream of our democracy.”You can live stream the questions faced by the Prime Minister on usual channels. PMQs will begin at the usual time of pm.BBC Parliament will be streaming PMQs via BBC iPlayer while Sky News will also be providing live coverage on Youtube.You will also be able to watch along at ParliamentTV which you can access here.

title: get-5-odeon-tickets-25-start-march
story: Tickets for theatres can be quite expensive, butyou plan to go to Odeon there is a discount available.Groupon is currently offering two tickets for £, or  you want to get a group together, you can get five tickets for £.The discount on tickets will not valid for Odeon Luxe cinemas however.If you want to go to one of Odeons Luxe cinemas a deal is still available at Groupon with two tickets for £ and five for £." alt"East Lothian Courier: Odeon tickets are available in bundles at Groupon " class"editor-image"Odeon tickets are available in bundles at GrouponThe tickets are available nationwide in  participating Odeon locations and theres no booking fee.Shoppers have got until March ,  to claim their bargain cinema ticket, and it can only be redeemed online on the Odeon website.The fine print states that there is a purchase limit of two or five per person, and the voucher is only valid for standard D screenings.Currently , plus people have already made use of the five tickets for £ deal, whilst over , plus have gone for the two tickets for £ deal.If you fancy adding to that tally, you can go to the Groupon website here to do so.

title: universal-credit-child-benefit-pension---full-list-benefits-rising-april-2022
story: Universal Credit, child benefit and statutory pension are among the payments that will be increased in April to keep up with the rising cost of living.Benefits will usually go up each year to keep up with inflation and in April claimants will see a .% rise in payments.The increase in payments comes as the energy price cap is set to rise by % and UK households will have to live on tighter budgets as everyday costs continue to rise.Here is how much benefits will rise in April .Standard allowanceExtra amounts for childrenLimited capability to workIf you are deemed to have limited capability to work the additional amount will rise from £. to £..If you are deemed to have limited capability to work or work-related activity the additional amount will rise from £. to £..Carer support for Universal Credit claimantsThe amount carers will get will rise from £. to £..Increased work allowanceHigher work allowancefor UC claimants with one or more dependants or limited capability to work with rise from £ to £.Lower work allowance for UC claimants with one or more dependants or limited capability to work with rise from £ to £.Single personLone parentCoupleOtherDependant aged under  – rise from £. to £.People who are retired on a low income will be topped up with Pension Credit.For single retirees it will rise from £. per week to £., for couples it will increase from £. to £..Attendance Allowance helps with extra costsyou have a disability severe enough that you need someone to help look after you.It’s paid at  dferent rates and how much you get depends on the level of care that you need because of your disability.You can claim Carer’s Allowanceyou care for someone at least  hours a week and they get certain benefits.In April, the rate will increase from £. to £. each week.The Disability Living Allowance is being replaced by Personal Independence Paymentfor disabled people.You can only apply for DLAyoure under . Older people whose DLA claim hasnt come to an end may see payments go up.For the mobility component:You can apply for Employment and Support Allowance you have a disability or health condition that affects how much you can work.Further rates are available for couple and those with disabilities or caring responsibilities.JSA provides support for those out of work while they look for a job. It is being replaced by Universal Credit but those still claiming JSA will see payments go up next year.Further rates are available for couple and those with disabilities or caring responsibilities.Statutory rates will rise from £. to £..New mums who don’t qualy for standard maternity pay could get payment from maternity allowance.This will rise from £. to £. in April.You get Child Benefityou’re responsible for bringing up a child who is:It’s paid every  weeks and there’s no limit to how many children you can claim for.Oldest or only child – rising from £. per week to £.Each child after that will rise form £ per week to £..Personal Independence Paymentcan help with extra living costsyou have both:You can get PIP evenyou’re working, have savings or are getting most other benefits.Statutory Sick Pay is currently paid by your employer for up to  weeks.The current rate of £. per week will rise to £. in April.For mor information about the benefits visit the government website.

title: east-coast-buses-hiring-new-drivers-musselburgh
story: The company, a subsidiary of Lothian Buses, is looking for both qualied PCVdrivers and those looking to start a new career.The positions are part of a recruitment drive taking place across the company throughout Edinburgh and the Lothians.The roles are considered perfect for those with great customer service skills with a passion of delivering a friendly and helpful service.Their trainee roles include full PCV training at the dedicated driver training school, flexible working hours and a competitive salary.Drivers will also be able to take advantage of free travel across Edinburgh and the surrounding area on buses and trams.Full details can be found at careers.lothianbuses

title: fly-australia-edinburgh-airport-tourism-reopens
story: Since the Covid- pandemic began in March , Australia has had a strict entry policy in place which meant the country was closed to visitors. Exemptions were only in place for Australian citizens, permanent residents and immediate family members of Australian citizens or permanent residents.But travellers can rejoice since the country is set to open the doors to vaccinated tourists and other visa holders from February , .Sunset at Sydney Harbour. Credit: Canva Unvaccinated visa holders will still need a valid travel exemption to enter Australia.Whether youre looking to tick off your bucket list or you want to plan a bargain break, weve got your back.                                                                                                                 We have rounded up the best flight deals available on Skyscanner from Edinburgh Airport to Australias main tourist hubs: Sydney, Perth, Adelaide and Melbourne. A map of Australia. title: tranent-man-burst-home-new-years-day-brandished-bottle
story: David Thomson entered the home at Morrison Avenue uninvited and began shouting and swearing at the occupants.Thomson then wielded the bottle and issued threats of violence during the incident.The -year-old was subsequently traced by police to his home at the town’s Young Avenue, where he proceeded to assault one officer by attempting to headbutt him.Thomson pleaded guilty to the two offences when he appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Tuesday.Sentence on Thomson was deferred to next month for the preparation of social work reports.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-plants-tree-mark-queens-platinum-jubilee
story: As part of the ‘plant a tree for the jubilee’ national initiative to mark the Queen’s platinum jubilee this year, pupils and staff held a ceremony with a small group of invited guests and planted a tree at the front of the school building.The tree – a fastigiate hornbeam, which is a compact form of the common hornbeam – can thrive in windy conditions.Gavin Clark, headteacher, said: “The Queen’s Green Canopy tree-planting initiative is co-ordinated by Lord Lieutenancies in every county across the UK.“At Preston Lodge we have a colleague on our teaching staff, Liz Nicoll, who is a Deputy Lieutenant for East Lothian and who was able to advise us more fully on how to get involved.“We planted the hornbeam on Monday, which was  years after Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II ascended to the throne.“This specimen tree not only recognises the platinum jubilee but is a welcome addition to the landscape of the school estate.“The hornbeam is a hardy species suited to cooler temperatures and which can support a iety of wildle so is also an important contributor to our school’s climate change ambitions.”Staff and students were joined by Roderick Urquhart, Lord Lieutenant for East Lothian Liz Nicoll and Hilary Cochran, Deputy Lord Lieutenants Monica Patterson, chief executive of East Lothian Council Norman Hampshire, council leader and Nicola McDowell, head of education at the council.A selection of Preston Lodge’s pipers and drummers started the short ceremony and, after a few words, head students Gregor Cargill and Georgia Murray planted the tree.

title: valentines-day-theme-north-berwick-floral-art-club-meeting
story: The group will welcome Angela Craig, of Catkins, to the town’s community centre.The meeting gets under way at pm and a spokeswoman said: “We look forward to welcoming all existing members, friends and visitors.”

title: last-chance-residents-say-new-transport-strategy-south-east-scotland
story: The South East of Scotland Transport Partnershipis encouraging people to submit their views and help shape the region’s transport strategy.The draft strategy includes transport policies for eight statutory local authorities: City of Edinburgh, Clackmannanshire, East Lothian, Falkirk, Fe, Midlothian, Scottish Borders and West Lothian.It sets out a framework for how transport and mobility will be provided, developed and improved in the region to make it more sustainable and economically active for the next  years and beyond.Gordon Edgar, chairperson of SEStran, said: “Transport affects how all of us live our daily lives, from where we choose to live and work, how we take children to school or visit the cinema, where we can get to easilywe are disabled and how we’ll get around as we get older.“We want to hear from as many people as possible to ensure our policies for the south-east of Scotland meet their needs and address their concerns.“Whether it’s better connections for rural areas, charging points for electric vehicles, safer cycling routes or more frequent and affordable bus and rail services, we want to hear how people from each of the local authorities feel about our proposals.“The pandemic changed how we work and travel, but we must prepare our transport system for the new normal and a net zero future.”The consultation closes at pm tomorrowand for more information go to sestran.gov.uk

title: variety-activities-offered-musselburgh-ageing-well
story: Tai Chi, Qi Gong and wellbeing classes are available on Thursdays, -.am, at the Fisherrow Centreand -.pm via Zoom .Tai Chi gradually builds suppleness and fitness, promotes better balance, can increase vitality and reduces feelings of stress.Booking is required by contacting Christine Dodson on   or cadodson@btinternetThe Warblers, a singing group for people with lung conditions, meets at Musselburgh East Community Centre on Mondays, .-.pm, with a Zoom option also available. The group also meets via Zoom on Tuesdays, -pm.The cost is £ £ or whatever an attendee can afford.The Warblers is part of a UK-wide singing-for-lung-health programme supported by British Lung Foundation.To book, contact Jane Lewis on  , Jane@gn.apc.org or go to warblers.org.ukAgeing Well’s health and wellbeing walks welcome adults of all ages.Those interested in taking part should meet outside Musselburgh Sports Centre at am on Wednesdaysor .am on Saturdays.Each walk lasts about an hour and no equipment is needed apart from a waterproof jacket and comfortable shoes.Walks are free but participants might want to bring some money for a hot drink afterwards. Some of the walks take a bus to dferent start locations once a month too. To book, contact Parvine Jazayeri, Ageing Well co-ordinator, at pjazayeri@eastlothian.gov.uk or on  .Musselburgh Rugby Club hosts a free Sporting Memories Foundation Scotland club, open to older sports fans who enjoy reminiscing about watching or playing sport.The weekly club, supported by a trained volunteer, provides a friendly, inclusive and welcoming environment and is especially keen to welcome those who might feel isolated through illness.The group meets on Wednesdays, .am-noon. Booking is required by contacting Gary Waddell on   or gary@thesmfWalking football can be enjoyed at Pinkie school on Mondays, .-.pm. It is a low-impact, modied version of the game, suitable for older men and women of all levels of ability and fitness.The first few sessions are free and then are £ every second month. Contact John Hood on   or johnhoodmwfc@gmail

title: hopes-new-mine-water-treatment-scheme-improve-water-quality-esk
story: The organisation held two online sessions recently to highlight the project, amid concern by Musselburgh and District Angling Clubabout the issue of mine water discharge, fearing it was having “a negative effect on the fish and invertebrate communities in the South Esk”.These concerns predate the recent pollution incident in the River Esk last month.Residents who attended the Coal Authority sessions heard more details about the plans for the treatment scheme at Dalkeith, which will remove iron and manganese from water flowing from a historical drainage tunnel adjacent to Newmills Road, known locally as Junkies Adit.The tunnel is linked tothe extensive underground coal mine workings in the Midlothian area.In recent years, the amount of mine water discharging from Junkies Adit has been increasing and the water quality has been deteriorating, the Coal Authority said.The organisation explained that the water affected was visibly orange, which was a result of naturally occurring iron dissolving in the mine water underground, which then became solid as it mixed with air and settled out of the water.In recent years, the discolouration has become more visible further downstream and could affect the river’s ecologyleft untreated, the Coal Authority added.The Coal Authority has been working with the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyand other partners to monitor the problem and develop a solution.Details for planning approval will be submitted shortly, with a view to starting the main construction later this year.More detailed design work will be done in the coming months to develop the scheme, and residents and stakeholders will have the chance to provide feedback as the designs progress.John Batty, Coal Authority project manager, said: “I think a lot of residents are keen to see this project progress as the river is so visibly orange as a result of the mine water, and the negative impact on the wildle and ecology is widely known.“The mine workings are complex so it has taken many years to get to this point.“We have been working to carry out studies and investigations, evaluate potential solutions and establish water quality by taking water samples on a regular basis through the challenges of the pandemic.“We have undertaken research using a test treatment scheme on site last spring that provided a large amount of information to feed into the designs.”Paul Butler, SEPA mining sector lead, said: “We are pleased that the progress we have made together has enabled the Coal Authority to provide information on the proposals for a new mine water treatment scheme at the site of Junkies Adit.”Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, said: “I think it is important that the public are involved with the process and it is vital public engagement continues as the scheme progresses.“I look forward to seeing the next stages of the treatment scheme and working with the Coal Authority, SEPA and the local community on this project.”Steven Dalgleish, of MDAA, said: “No faulting the Coal Authority’s commitment to the cause but the association remains gravely concerned that funding may not appear for this project.“From some of our own research, it seems that this may remain an issue for over  years, leaving the South Esk between Dalkeith and its junction with the North Esk effectively dead and useless as the main salmon and sea trout spawning bed area it once was.”

title: day-today-prestonpans-shut-due-covid-energy-price-rises
story: Thanks from the East Lothian community have been shared across social media following the news that Day-Today – also know locally as Ashiq’s – is to close.A number of factors have contributed to owner Ferhan Ashiq’s decision to close his Redburn Road shop for good on February .Ferhan told the Courier that “the writing on the wall” came when Covid struck the county two years ago.This coincided with a serious burn injury to Ferhan and we Hira’s youngest son which put “stress on the business, with hours reduced to take care of him”.Additionally, Ferhan confirmed that the Day-Today store was also facing a huge surge in electric costs – a rise from £, per year to £, – which he said was an “insurmountable” price, putting the business in an “untenable situation”.He added: “With the costs of goods rising as it was, in good conscience could I really be asking the people of Prestonpans to be paying more for their products “I saw the writing on the wall – their own energy pricing will be going up and,anything, they will be needing to make their money go as far as possible, so we as a family decided we will leave before we are pushed.”Energy price rises for homes and businesses will continue after Ofgem announced that average energy bills will increase by £ from April – a rise of  per cent.Pandemic isolation rules put further pressure on staff and the Ashiq family.Ferhan added: “Running a store of that size is quite an undertaking: you end up working -hour days, seven days a week for three years, no holidays, no breaks.“Isolation measures put pressure on staff members covering other shts and working much harder.”Thanking the Prestonpans community, the shop owner said: “Our family is so thankful to everyone who helped us achieve what we have in Prestonpans for the last  years.“This business put myself and my sister through education and we both went to university off the back of it, and that could never have happenedthe community hadn’t shopped in our store.“I went to school with a lot of customers and I’m watching their kids grow up and become friends with my kids.”It has been confirmed that Day-Today has been sold and will “never be a convenience store again” – the new owner and business will not be revealed until March .The Ashiq family plans to stay in Prestonpans for the foreseeable future, while the family’s Levenhall Village Store in Musselburgh will remain open.Ferhan said: “I am looking to devote more time to my lovely we Hira, who has stood by me all these years throughout all the hardships, and my young children Harris, Niall and Daniel.”The alleged theft from the premises was reported to police, who are understood to be investigating the matter.

title: east-lothian-council-leader-norman-hampshire-standing-re-election
story: Norman Hampshire is Labour’s candidate for the Dunbar and East Linton ward in May’s East Lothian Council elections.The dad-of-three has been a member of the local authority in East Lothian for more than  years.He was first elected in  but lost his seat to Stephen Bunyan, former Dunbar Community Council chairman and teacher at Dunbar Grammar School, four years later.Mr Hampshire, who lives in Dunbar with his we, was re-elected in  and has been involved with the council ever since.He became depute leader in May  and succeeded his colleague Willie Innes, who died last year, as council leader.Mr Hampshire, who is the council’s spokesman for the environment and chairman of the planning committee, said: “I am proud to have had the honour of representing Dunbar, the town where I was born and have always lived, for over  years.“I have always sought to stand up for its interests and those of the whole ward, and serve my constituents to the very best of my ability.“I have a very positive record on which to seek re-election at the election in May.“I have played a leading role in an administration which has shown strong leadership during one of the most dficult periods we have faced in living memory.”Mr Hampshire highlighted the dficulties facing the local authority in the face of the coronavirus pandemic and challenging financial circumstances.He said: “These key issues – protecting services, supporting communities and boosting the economy – will continue to be at the heart of the manesto that we present to voters in May.“I hope people in this ward and across East Lothian will put their faith in me and my Labour colleagues to continue our work helping make East Lothian the best place to live, work, visit and play.”Mr Hampshire is the second candidate confirmed for the Dunbar and East Linton ward, which also covers villages including Stenton, Spott and Innerwick.David Mumford retired as rector of the Scottish Episcopal Church in Brechin in . Now living in Innerwick, he will represent the Greens during the election.Already, Labour has confirmed Provost John McMillan and Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who represent the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, and Councillors Colin McGinn and Fiona Dugdale, who represent the Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry ward, are standing for re-election.Meanwhile, recently elected Colin Yorkston is also aiming to retain his seat in the Preston Seton Gosford ward for Labour.The Conservatives have confirmed that Councillor Jeremy Findlay is hoping to retain his seat in the North Berwick Coastal ward and could be joined by Judy Lockhart-Hunter, the current chairperson of North Berwick Community Council.The Conservatives have also confirmed George McGuire as their candidate for the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.The Scottish Green Party has announced Shona McIntosh , Tim Porteus , Jackie Swailesand Jacq Cottrellas candidates in addition to Mr Mumford.Stuart Crawford has been confirmed as the Liberal Democrats candidate for the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Labour, the Conservatives and SNP have all also confirmed that two of their sitting councillors will be stepping down.Jim Goodfellowand Fiona ODonnell are not seeking re-election in May for Labour, while Jane Hendersonand Craig Hoy– who was elected as a South Scotland MSP last year – are stepping down for the Conservatives.Finally, SNP Group leader Stuart Currieand Paul McLennan– who was elected as East Lothian MSP last May – are also standing down.
